attachments.text:
Carefully guide your nation from the era of absolute monarchies in the early 19th century, through expansion and colonization, to finally become a truly great power by the dawn of the 20th century.
<br>
<br>												<strong>Victoria II</strong> is a grand strategy game played during the colonial era of the 19th century, where the player takes control of a country, guiding it through industrialisation, political reforms, military conquest, and colonization.
<br>												
<br>												Experience an in-depth political simulation where every action you take will have various consequences all over the world. The population will react to your decisions based on their political awareness, social class, as well as their willingness to accept or revolt against their government.
<br>												
<br>												<strong>Key features:</strong>
<br>												<ul class="bb_ul"><li>Deep engrossing political simulation with dozens of different governments.
<br>												</li><li>Detailed economy with over fifty different types of goods and various production factories.
<br>												</li><li>Over 200 different countries can be played, during the era stretching from 1835 to the onset of WWII.
<br>												</li><li>Advanced Technological system with thousands of inventions to discover.
<br>												</li><li>Improved graphics and interface, as well as multiplayer support.
<br>												</li><li>A streamlined interface makes the game easily accessible.
<br>												</li><li>Automation of various tasks including, trade and population promotion.
<br>												</li><li>Advanced spheres of influences system, where the great powers battle over the control of the world.
<br>												</li><li>Cottage production simulating pre-industrial economies.
<br>												</li><li>Gunboat Diplomacy, no need for negotiating as a fleet outside a port may be a more persuasive argument.
<br>												</li><li>Historical and Dynamic missions guiding your country through the history.
<br>												</li></ul>

attachments.title: Pokémon Go Strips Users Of Their Legal Rights; Here’s How To Opt Out
attachments.text:
Let&rsquo;s be honest: just about every single one of us agrees to Terms of Service without ever reading what we&rsquo;re signing away. It&rsquo;s no different for craze-of-the-week Pok&eacute;mon Go, a game with a clause in its terms that strips you of your right to file a lawsuit against the company. However, if you&rsquo;re one of the many people who just started using the app in the last few days, you still have time to opt out and preserve your constitutional right to a jury trial.
The Pok&eacute;mon Go Terms of Service, as published by developer Niantic Labs, include a restrictive forced arbitration clause that both takes away the user&rsquo;s right to file a lawsuit against Niantic, but also bars the user from joining others in any sort of class action against the company.
Instead, all legal disputes must be heard &mdash; on an individual basis &mdash; through private arbitration outside of a courtroom. Each user must mount their own case, even if all of the plaintiff users were wronged in the same exact way by the company.
So, imagine if there&rsquo;s a huge data breach that results in the leaking of personal information for millions of Go users. Rather than have to answer for the totality of the error, the company would only have to face those few users who take the time &mdash; and have the resources &mdash; to bring a case before an arbitrator.
Even though those few users may bring identical cases to arbitration, there is always the chance that the arbitrator could rule differently in each instance. And if that arbitrator makes a mistake that would have changed the outcome, the Supreme Court has previously ruled that you&rsquo;d have no recourse through the legal system.
SO HOW DO I OPT OUT OF THIS?
The Go terms do include an opt-out provision for people who don&rsquo;t want to give up their rights. However, you must opt out within 30 days of first agreeing to the Terms of Service. 
Luckily, many Pok&eacute;mon Go users have only downloaded and activated the app in the last week, meaning they are still within that timeframe. 
To Opt Out: Send an email ASAP (before the 30 days have passed) to <mailto:termsofservice@nianticlabs.com|termsofservice@nianticlabs.com> with &ldquo;Arbitration Opt-out Notice&rdquo; in the subject line and a clear declaration that you are opting out of the arbitration clause in the Pok&eacute;mon Go terms of service. 
Was this helpful? We&rsquo;re a non-profit! You can get more stories like this in our twice weekly ad-free newsletter! Click here to sign up.
attachments.fallback: Consumerist Link: Pokémon Go Strips Users Of Their Legal Rights; Here’s How To Opt Out

text: tl;dr; in the ToC (the thing no one fucking reads ever) there’s a clause where you agree to settle any disputes with niantic in a private arbitrage court, as opposed to regular legal options. You need to send them an email within 30 days of creating your account informing them that you don’t agree to this clause.
and then you can sue them.
unlikely scenario, but still kinda sick they included that clause in the first place.
Hm, afaik lots of companies do that

```
You and eBay each agree that any and all disputes or claims that have arisen or may arise between you and eBay […] shall be resolved exclusively through final and binding arbitration, rather than in court. 
```

This also seems to be an US exclusive thing. If you check the same paragraph for example <http://ebay.de|ebay.de> and <http://ebay.co.uk|ebay.co.uk>, you won’t find the same arbitration clause. Pretty sure it’s not legal everywhere to do this
